title-group.article-title: Design of an active roll control system for hybrid four-wheel-drive vehicles

abstract.p: This paper presents a method for designing an active roll control system, combined with integrated chassis control for hybrid four-wheel-drive vehicles. The active roll control system adopts an active anti-roll bar as an actuator and is designed by model matching control with a roll estimator. To maintain the manoeuvrability of hybrid four-wheel-drive vehicles with an active roll control system, integrated chassis control is adopted. The hybrid four-wheel-drive vehicle consists of a front internal-combustion engine and independent motor-driven rear wheels and is equipped with electronic stability control, active front steering and four-wheel drive. Direct yaw moment control is used to generate a control yaw moment. Weighted pseudo-inverse-based control allocation and simulation-based optimization are proposed to distribute the control yaw moment. Simulations on the vehicle simulation software CarSim® show that the proposed active roll control system with integrated chassis control is effective for controlling the roll motion and the yaw motion of a hybrid four-wheel-drive vehicle.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: An active roll control system (ARCS) has been developed for the purpose of enhancing the ride comfort or preventing vehicle rollover against external disturbances such as the lateral acceleration.1 Most of the previously developed ARCSs have concentrated on the ride comfort, i.e. reduction in the roll angle, which is caused by the lateral acceleration. As a by-product, the ARCS is also helpful for rollover prevention because untripped rollover is also caused by an excessive lateral acceleration.2 ARCSs have been implemented with an active suspension or semi-active damping control or an active anti-roll bar (AARB) as an actuator. An active suspension is very effective in controlling the bounce, roll and pitch motions. On the other hand, an AARB is very effective in controlling the roll motion of a vehicle.3 In this paper, an AARB is adopted as an actuator for the ARCS because it is relatively cheap and simple.

There have been several methods for designing a controller for the ARCS such as using lateral-acceleration-based proportional–derivative control,4 linear quadratic (LQ) Gaussian control with loop transfer recovery,5 gain-scheduled H∞ control6 and sliding-mode control2. In this paper, model-matching control is adopted to design a controller for the ARCS because it is simple and powerful. For designing a controller for the ARCS, it is necessary to measure or estimate the roll angle and the roll rate. For this purpose, several methods have been proposed.7 Most of these research studies have adopted a closed-loop observer. However, it is difficult to measure the roll rate or the roll angular acceleration in estimating the roll angle. In this paper, an open-loop observer that is driven by the measured lateral acceleration is adopted.8

Generally, the ARCS has a tendency to make the controlled vehicle exhibit a rear-sway phenomenon. As a result, the controlled vehicle drifts. This means a loss of manoeuvrability. To maintain the manoeuvrability, integrated chassis control (ICC) with electronic stability control (ESC), active front steering (AFS) and four-wheel drive (4WD) which are available in hybrid four-wheel-drive vehicles (H4Vs) is proposed.

Over the last two decades, much research and development for hybrid electrical vehicles (HEVs) have been carried out. In this development, several configurations have been proposed in designing HEVs such as serial, parallel and combined configurations.9 Among these types of HEV, an H4V is a good candidate for fuel economy and vehicle chassis control. Figure 1 shows the configuration of the H4V developed by MIRA.10,11 Besides the advantages such as the minimized costs, small technical issues, even weight distribution and simplest packaging, the capability of vehicle chassis control can be significantly improved by combining ESC, AFS and 4WD, which is provided by the independent motor-driven rear wheels in an H4V.

caption.p: Schematic view of the H4V hybrid powertrain.

sec.p: ICC for H4Vs has a two-level structure: an upper-level controller and a lower-level controller. In the upper-level controller, direct yaw moment control is applied to generate a control yaw moment which is needed to stabilize a vehicle. In the lower-level controller, the control yaw moment is distributed using weighted pseudo-inverse-based control allocation (WPCA) with ESC, AFS and 4WD. WPCA is a good candidate because it can solve the problem in real time through algebraic computation.12–14 To represent the actuator configuration of ESC, AFS and 4WD in WPCA formulation, variable weightings of the objective function in WPCA are proposed. In order to find optimal weights, simulation-based optimization is proposed. To check the effectiveness of the proposed method, simulations are performed with the vehicle simulation package CarSim®.15

This paper is organized as follows. In the second section, an ARCS is designed with model-matching control based on a one-degree-of-freedom (1DOF) roll model, and Bode plot analysis is performed. In the third section, a direct yaw moment controller is designed with a bicycle model, and yaw moment distribution schemes based on WPCA and simulation-based optimization are presented. In the fourth section, simulations are performed via CarSim. The conclusions are given in the fifth section.

sec.title: Design of an active roll control system
sec.p: In this section, an ARCS is designed by model-matching control with a roll estimator.

sec.title: Design of a controller for an AARB
sec.p: A 1DOF roll model, as shown in Figure 2, is used to design a controller. This model describes the roll motion of a vehicle. The equation of motion is

where Kϕ and Cϕ are the roll stiffness and the roll damping coefficient respectively. In real applications, the roll angle and roll rate are hard to measure. Also, the measurement devices for these quantities are quite expensive. Therefore, it is necessary to estimate the roll angle and the roll rate with an observer. In this paper, the roll angle and the roll rate are estimated by an open-loop observer, which is simply integrating equation (1) driven by the lateral acceleration ay.8 Figure 3 shows the block diagram of the open-loop observer. Contrary to a closed-loop observer, this observer requires only the lateral acceleration signal. A closed-loop observer can give a more accurate estimation with measurements of the roll rate and the lateral acceleration. However, if there is only one measurement of the lateral acceleration, it is sufficient to use an open-loop observer which can estimate those values with relatively good accuracy. According to previous research,8 the open-loop observer driven by the lateral acceleration will work well under the condition that there are no rough roads and wheel lift (roll angles below about 8°) in spite of changes in the vehicle parameters caused by payload variations.

sec.p: The disturbance considered in this paper is the lateral acceleration. As pointed out in previous work,8 the uncertainty in the parameters of the roll dynamics is caused by payload variations. The model-matching control is known to be robust against the parameter uncertainty and the disturbance. For this reason, model-matching control is adopted to design a controller for the ARCS.

sec.title: Simulation of the open-loop observer
sec.p: To check the estimation performance of the open-loop observer, an experiment was performed on a real vehicle. The initial speed of the vehicle is 80 km/h, and the steering input is a single-lane-change manoeuvre. The roll angle and the roll rate were measured with a Differential Global Positioning System–Inertial Navigation System RT3000 from Oxford Technology Solutions. Figure 4 shows the experimental and simulation results of the open-loop observer for a single-lane-change manoeuvre. Figure 4(a) and (b) show the measured steering-wheel angle and the lateral acceleration respectively obtained from the real experiment. The lateral acceleration in Figure 4(b) was fed into the open-loop observer. Figure 4(c) and (d) show the roll angle and the roll rate respectivelyy obtained from the experiment and the open-loop observer. As shown in Figure 4, the estimated roll angle and roll rate from the open-loop observer fit well to those of the real vehicle. From this result, it can be concluded that the roll angle and the roll rate that are estimated with the open-loop observer can be fed to the controller for the AARB.

sec.title: Bode plot analysis of the proposed ARCS
sec.p: The proposed ARCS is analysed and compared with the previous work using H∞ norms and a Bode plot analysis in the frequency domain. For comparison, LQ static output feedback (SOF) control based on a linear four-degree-of-freedom roll plane model was considered.16 In previous work,16 the LQ objective function in LQ SOF control contained the terms emphasizing the vertical acceleration, the roll acceleration, the roll angle, the roll rate, the suspension stroke, the tyre deflection and the control roll moment. When determining the weights in the LQ objective function, two cases of weights, namely case 1 and case 2, are considered for comparison. Case 1 and case 2 emphasize the reductions in the roll angle and roll rate, and the reductions in the suspension stroke and tyre deflection respectively.
The target vehicle model is a small-sized SUV, namely SmallSUV, provided in CarSim. Table 1 shows the parameters of the 1DOF roll model that are referred to in the SmallSUV model.

caption.p: Parameters and values of the SmallSUV model in CarSim.

sec.p: Table 2 and Figure 5 show the H∞ norms and the Bode plots from the lateral acceleration to the roll angle, roll rate, suspension stroke and tyre deflection. Because the controller for the ARCS given in equation (4) is linear, it can be represented as an SOF form u = Ky. The frequency range for the response under the lateral acceleration is near 0.5–1 Hz. Hence, the frequency responses below 1 Hz should be focused on. In Table 2 and Figure 5, the columns and curves labelled ARCS, Case 1 and Case 2 represent the data for the proposed ARCS, for the controller obtained from LQ SOF control with the weight of case 1 and for the controller obtained from LQ SOF control with the weight of case 2 respectively. As shown in Table 2 and Figure 5, the proposed ARCS shows a performance comparable with those of case 1 and case 2. In previous work,16 case 1 and case 2 showed good performances in controlling the roll angle and the roll rate under an excessive lateral acceleration. From these results, it is expected that the proposed ARCS is effective in controlling the roll motion of a vehicle.

sec.title: Simulations study
sec.p: As presented in previous work,16 a vehicle under an excessive lateral acceleration easily drifts. The lateral load transfer caused by an excessive lateral acceleration makes the vertical tyre forces of the inner wheels approach zero, and those of the outer wheels twice the original vertical tyre force. Under the situation, the lateral force of the front outer wheel becomes larger than that of the rear outer wheel because the front side is heavier than the rear side. As a result of this, the vehicle turns around the front outer wheel. This is a rear-sway phenomenon. The use of an AARB or active suspension deepens the rear-sway phenomenon because the inner wheels are lifted more quickly. Figure 6 illustrates this situation. The rear-sway phenomenon indicates the loss of manoeuvrability of the vehicle with an ARCS. The loss of manoeuvrability may cause another accident such as a crash or a tripped rollover.

caption.p: Drift mechanism under a high lateral acceleration with an ARCS.

sec.p: To cope with the loss of the manoeuvrability, it is necessary to adopt a method which controls the yaw motion of a vehicle using an ARCS. For this purpose, several approaches have been proposed.17–19 The main idea of these research studies is to control the roll moment distribution between the front axle and the rear axle for the purpose of stabilizing the yaw motion of a vehicle. To check the effectiveness of an ARCS with the roll moment distribution method in controlling the yaw and roll motions of a vehicle, simulations were performed. Three roll moment distribution schemes were considered: a roll moment acting on only the front axle (ARCS/F), a roll moment acting on only the rear axle (ARCS/R) and a roll moment acting on both the front axle and the rear axle (ARCS/FR).

The initial speed of the vehicle was set to 80 km/h, and the tyre–road friction coefficient was set to 0.85. It was assumed that there are no speed controls to maintain a constant velocity. The maximum roll moment of these AARBs was limited to 1500 N m. The actuator of the AARB was modelled as a first-order system with a time constant of 0.05. The steering input is a sine-with-dwell manoeuvre, which is defined in NHTSA standard FMVSS No. 126.20 The maximum steering angle of the manoeuvre is obtained from a test in which the lateral acceleration is slowly increased until it reaches 0.3g. For the SmallSUV, the maximum steering angle of the sine-with-dwell manoeuvre was 227.5°.

Figures 7 and 8 show the simulation results and the trajectories of the open-loop system and ARCS respectively. As shown in Figure 7(a), the ARCS/FR gave the smallest roll angle. However, the uncontrolled vehicle and the vehicle with the ARCS/FR and ARCS/R drifted because of the rear-sway phenomenon, as shown in Figure 8. As a result, the vehicle with the ARCS/FR and ARCS/R moved backwards after 4.3 s and the side-slip angles diverged, as shown in Figure 7(c) and (d). Only the vehicle with the ARCS/F did not drift. However, the vehicle with the ACRS/F showed a relatively large roll angle, compared with the vehicle with the ARCS/FR. In addition to this, the yaw rate error of the vehicle with the ARCS/F was still large, as shown in Figure 7(b). Generally, the yaw rate error is smaller than 0.08 rad/s (=4.7 deg/s) under normal driving. The maximum yaw rate error of the ARCS/F is 33.5 deg/s, and this means a loss of manoeuvrability, i.e. a loss of yaw-rate-tracking performance, compared with normal driving. This result indicates that the ARCS causes the yaw motion of the controlled vehicle to deteriorate regardless of the roll moment distribution schemes. Under this situation, it is desirable to use an ARCS/FR for roll control because it can give the smallest roll angle, as shown in Figure 7(a). When using an ARCS/FR for roll control, it is necessary to design a yaw moment controller in order to maintain manoeuvrability.

sec.p: For conventional vehicles, it is natural to design a yaw motion controller such as braking-based ESC.21 However, braking-based ESC has drawbacks such as the discomfort caused by the application of the brake. To reduce the discomfort caused by a brake, AFS or 4WD can be a good candidate. For example, ESC and AFS were integrated in controlling the yaw motion of a vehicle so as to minimize the braking pressure.21 Also, 4WD or independent motor-driven rear wheels combined with ESC and AFS can enhance the ride comfort and the performance of yaw motion control.10,11 In this paper, an integrated chassis controller with ESC, AFS and 4WD that are available in H4Vs is designed in order to maintain manoeuvrability.

sec.title: Integrated chassis control for H4Vs
sec.p: In this section, an ICC for H4Vs is designed. The ICC has a two-level structure: an upper-level controller and a lower-level controller. In the upper-level controller, the control yaw moment is computed with direct yaw moment control. In the lower-level controller, the control yaw moment is distributed with ESC, AFS and 4WD available in H4Vs.

sec.title: Design of the lower-level controller
sec.p: Once the control yaw moment MB is computed, it should be distributed to the braking forces of ESC or the additional steering angle of AFS or the traction forces of 4WD. In this paper, WPCA is adopted to distribute the control yaw moments with ESC, AFS and 4WD that are available in H4Vs.

In Figure 10(b), Fx4 is the longitudinal traction force generated from the rear motor, and Fyf is the lateral tyre force that is converted into the AFS angle. These tyre forces should be determined to generate the control yaw moment MB. WPCA is used to determine the tyre forces.

In this paper, two actuator configurations, namely ESC and ESC+AFS+4WD (=ICC), in the H4V are considered. For these actuator configurations, a particular physical constraint on the yaw moment distribution is needed. For example, if only ESC is used and the control yaw moment is positive, then the longitudinal braking forces of the left wheels, i.e. Fx1 and Fx3 in Figure 10(a), should be generated and those of the right wheels, i.e. Fx2 and Fx4, should not be generated. If there are available traction forces in the rear wheels by virtue of 4WD, then Fx4 should be generated, as shown in Figure 10(b).

In order to obtain these actuator configurations, the weighting factor ρ in equation (13) is introduced. If the weighting factor ρi in ρ is decreased, then the corresponding tyre force Fxi or Fyf is increased, and vice versa. sec.p:

sec.p: WPCA given in equations (12) and (13) can always find the optimum solution, as given in equation (14). However, the optimum tyre forces zopt cannot always be generated in each wheel. For instance, the optimum tyre forces cannot be generated under saturation of the tyre forces. In order to cope with saturation of the tyre forces, constrained WPCA can be used.24 This approach tries to generate the control yaw moment with the constrained control input, e.g. z−≤z≤z+, which is derived from the friction circle of a tyre. However, WPCA with bounded or inequality constraints requires a longer computation time than that of WPCA because it runs an iterative optimization. In this paper, the variable weights for limiting the excessive tyre slip ratio and the front tyre slip angle, given in Figure 11 and equation (17), are proposed in order to determine the saturation of the tyre forces in WPCA.

sec.title: Simulation
sec.p: In this section, simulations are performed to check the performance for ICC, combined with the ARCS. The simulation conditions were identical with those in the previous section. Table 3 shows the parameters of the 2DOF bicycle model, which were obtained from the SmallSUV model in CarSim. The actuators of the brake and the AFS were modelled as a first-order system with time constants of 0.12 and 0.05 respectively. The ABS provided in CarSim is used to prevent locking of the brake in the front wheels. The operating range of the slip ratio in the ABS is between 0.05 and 0.2. The electrical motor that the rear wheels is equipped with has a 250 N m peak torque and a reduction belt drive with a 3:1 ratio. The motor torque–speed characteristic has been given in previous work.10,11 For the actuator configuration, simulation-based optimization was performed to find the optimum set of εi in equation (20).

sec.p: Table 4 shows the variable weights obtained from simulation-based optimization. As shown in Table 4, the rear braking force is expected to be very small for ICC because ε3 corresponding to rear braking is quite large compared with the other ε values. Table 5 shows the comparison result between the controllers. In Table 5, the heading ICC represents the actuator configuration ESC+AFS+4WD. As shown in this table, the vehicle with the ARCS showed an improved result in controlling the roll motion compared with that without the ARCS. However, the yaw rate error and the side-slip angle were increased by the ARCS. The advantages of ICC in controlling the roll motion are the increase in the final vehicle speed and the reduction in the yaw rate error at the expense of the increased side-slip angle.

sec.p: Figure 12 shows the simulation results for each actuator configuration with the ARCS. As shown in Figure 12, the controlled vehicles with the ARCS, i.e. ESC+ARCS and ICC+ARCS, did not drift by virtue of ESC and ICC. On the other hand, the final vehicle speed of ICC drastically increases compared with that of ESC, while maintaining the same level of the yaw rate error and the side-slip angle, as shown in Figure 12(c), (d) and (e). This is caused by the fact that the braking force is reduced by virtue of AFS and 4WD in ICC. From these results, it can be concluded that ICC with ESC, AFS and 4WD available in H4Vs can significantly improve the performance of yaw motion control.

sec.p: As shown in Figure 12(c), (d) and (e), the yaw rate errors and the side-slip angles of the controlled vehicles with the ARCS were increased, and the final speeds were decreased, compared with those of the controlled vehicles without the ARCS. This means that the ARCS caused the vehicle stability performance to deteriorate owing to the larger braking input resulting from the large yaw rate error although it significantly reduced the roll angle, as pointed out in the second section. The large yaw rate error is generated by the rear-sway phenomenon of the ARCS. This fact explains the difference between the vehicle speeds of ICC and ICC+ARCS or ESC and ESC+ARCS, as shown in Figure 12(e).

Figure 13 shows the control roll moment of the AARB, the AFS angle, the braking pressures of the front wheels and traction or braking torques of the rear wheels for each actuator configuration. In Figure 13(d) and (e), the curves with the labels FL, FR, RL and RR are those for the front left wheel, the front right wheel, the rear left wheel and the rear right wheel respectively. The control roll moments of the AARBs are nearly identical, as shown in Figure 13(a). The AFS angles of ICC+ARCS are slightly larger than those of ICC because the control yaw moment of ICC+ARCS is larger than that of ICC, as shown in Figure 13(b) and (c). As shown from Figure 13(d), the braking pressures of ICC are smaller than those of ESC since AFS and 4WD reduce the braking effort. As shown in Figure 13(e), only the traction torque was applied for ICC in order to maximize the performance of vehicle stability control. This means that the combination of the braking of the front inner wheel and the traction torque of the rear outer wheel is the most effective way to generate the yaw moment. However, this also means that regenerative braking is not available in the rear wheels.

sec.p: Figure 14 shows the trajectories of the uncontrolled and controlled vehicles for each actuator configuration. As mentioned earlier, the uncontrolled vehicle and the controlled vehicle with only the ARCS drifted by the rear-sway phenomenon. As shown in Figure 14, the vehicles with ESC or ICC did not drift. The vehicles with ESC and ESC+ARCS travelled a shorter distance caused by the large braking input of ESC, as shown in Figure 13(d). On the other hand, the vehicle with ICC travelled a longer distance by virtue of the motor-driven rear wheel. Because of the large braking input caused by the rear-sway phenomenon, the vehicle with the ARCS exhibited a slight oversteer characteristic, compared with a vehicle with only ESC or ICC.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this paper, an ARCS with ICC for H4Vs was proposed. The roll angle and the roll rate were estimated using the open-loop observer by simply integrating the roll angular acceleration, which is obtained from the 1DOF roll model driven by the lateral acceleration. The ARCS was designed with model-matching control. To check the performance of the proposed ARCS, Bode plot analysis and a simulations study were performed. To maintain the manoeuvrability and the lateral stability, ICC was designed. In ICC, WPAC was adopted to coordinate the actuator configuration ESC+AFS+4WD available in H4Vs. To use WPCA for the yaw moment distribution, variable weightings corresponding to the actuator configuration were proposed. Simulation-based optimization was proposed to improve the yaw moment distribution. Through simulations, it was shown that the proposed ARCS can effectively reduce the roll angle and the roll rate, and that the simulation-based optimization can significantly improve vehicle stability for H4Vs.
